summary: This is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing access to scanned documents from the Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The emails focus on obtaining draft indictments and defense attorney letters, which are stored on a shared drive.

persons.name: Kurland, Abigail
persons.context: Appears as a recipient (Cc) in an email discussing access to Epstein investigation files.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Sender of an email confirming receipt of files and offering to arrange shared drive access for colleagues to view Epstein case materials.

persons.name: Lou
persons.context: Mentioned as the person to contact to obtain share drive access for the Epstein case files.

connections.description: Both are copied on internal SDNY emails coordinating access to Epstein investigation documents.

events.title: Email Request for Epstein Documents
events.description: An SDNY prosecutor requests scanned documents from a trip, specifically draft indictments and defense submissions related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Confirmation of File Receipt
events.description: Alex confirms receipt of Epstein case files but notes they are too large for email, prompting an offer to set up shared drive access.

events.title: Reaction to Case Materials
events.description: An email with the subject "Re: Epstein" contains the reaction "Double wow," indicating the significant or shocking nature of the materials being discussed.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: SDNY prosecutors in January 2019 were actively seeking and reviewing scanned documents from the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
The sought materials included draft indictments and letters from Epstein's defense attorneys, indicating a review of prior prosecutorial decisions.
Case files were stored on a shared drive (\clowANYS\StAndrews\Share\USvEpstein-2018R01618\Investigation\#Florida Scans\), and access was being coordinated internally.
The reaction "Double wow" in an email suggests the content of the Epstein case materials was considered remarkable or shocking by those reviewing them.
